title: The use of : in str.format()
author: t2_x534b
text:
print('This number {:.2f} is a percentage'.format(76.8399))

Can someone explain the use of the `:` thingy in the first {} brackets?

comments.author: Diapolo10
comments.body:
It lets you add format specifiers. The parameter index (if any) goes to the left, the formatting rules to the right.

Also works in f-strings, with the content on the left:

    print(f'This number {76.8399:.2f} is a percentage')

EDIT: This may interest you: https://docs.python.org/3/library/string.html#format-specification-mini-language

comments.author: kyber
comments.body:
Format instructions, .2f means decimal point, two decimal places (rounded), floating point.

f-strings use same formatting instructions.

    print(f'This number {76.8399:.2f} is a percentage')

Check the docs for more instructions including <^> for justification, padding (spaces, zeros, or other characters).

https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/string.html#formatspec
